image.altText: A young girl sits at a table smiling. A worksheet is in front of her

items.synopsis: At a school near Alice Springs, children and their parents are learning the severely endangered language of Pertame. It's just one example of a national push to revitalise Indigenous languages for the next generation.

title.children: This Indigenous language has just 20 fluent speakers left. This playgroup aims to save it

image.altText: A boat floats in the water near a Chinese ship.

items.synopsis: In the face of a David and Goliath battle to maintain control over the islands of Kalayaan, which are still administered by Manila, in the South China Sea, the Philippines has turned to two very different forces: soldiers and holiday makers.

title.children: The Philippines is in a David and Goliath battle with China. But has Manila found a sneaky workaround?

image.altText: hands hold colourful leaflets that read Tes 23

items.synopsis: As the campaign for the Voice referendum begins, it's worth having a look at why this referendum question has become so hopelessly ensnarled in undergrowth. And perhaps doing a spot of weeding, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: The referendum is a Yes/No vote on 102 words. All other disputes should be shut out

image.altText: Julia Baird, who is wearing a blue swim cap and goggles submerged in the sea, looks back at the shore in warm morning sunlight

items.synopsis: For awe hunters, the everyday is often the extraordinary and the smallest wonders can be transformative. Their secrets can be yours, too — you just need to open your eyes.

title.children: On dark days, through chronic illness, hunting awe has saved me. It can transform your life, too

image.altText: David and Julie Bland sitting out the front of their now-renovated Queenslander house that was moved from inner Brisbane.

items.synopsis: When David and Julie Bland's house burned down, they wanted to replicate the character and authenticity of their grand old Queenslander — but faced with the increasing costs of building materials and a lengthy wait, they opted to recycle an existing home instead.

title.children: Would you slice your dream house in two? These couples did just that

image.altText: A woman stands in front of a canola crop

items.synopsis: Minerals mined deep under Canadian soil are turned into fertilisers that are used on Australian farms to produce the food that feeds the world. But as some countries take steps to curb fertiliser use, farmers fear they too could be faced with restrictions.

title.children: For Sally it's a simple prospect yet governments globally are taking steps to curb what she's doing

image.altText: An old man wearing a suit looking stunned and sad being talked to by a man while a woman grabs his arm

items.synopsis: A senator's troubling freeze-up in front of the cameras this week has fuelled a national conversation about whether America's politicians are too old.

title.children: After an elderly senator's freeze-up, the US debates how old's too old to govern

image.altText: Bird's eyeview of a circular, sprawling city in the desert.

items.synopsis: Burning Man festival-goers are told to conserve food and water as access to Nevada's Black Rock desert is "closed for the remainder of the event" due to heavy rain.

title.children: Burning Man festival-goers trapped in Nevada desert as rain floods the site

image.altText: A photo of a large concrete statue of a man performing a facepalm pose

items.synopsis: Yes, dad jokes can be fun. They play an important role in how we interact with our kids. But dad jokes may also help prepare them to handle embarrassment later in life, write Shane Rogers and Marc Hye-Knudsen.

title.children: Dad jokes are about much more than punchlines. It turns out they can bring surprising benefits to your kids

image.altText: Tall buildings against the sky

items.synopsis: With no existing blueprint, Singapore wants to regulate the social phenomenon to better support public discourse. Experts cast their doubts and say existing laws in Australia could help.

title.children: Singapore wants to be the first to outlaw cancel culture. But can it be done? Here's what experts say

image.altText: Angie Bain crouches next to Winnie the Groodle at Fremantle's training base in Cockburn

items.synopsis: In the high-pressure environment of AFL and AFLW, the Fremantle Dockers are using a new type of ball magnet to help bring success. And this one has four legs.

title.children: Is this Fremantle's most important ball winner? How Winnie the groodle helps the Dockers perform

image.altText: a man smiling with four bulldogs

items.synopsis: Defence lawyers told a bail hearing his stepfather controlled every aspect of his life — from his finances, to what he ate, and his relationships.

title.children: He was the youngest councillor in Gold Coast's history, held in the 'highest esteem' by the mayor. Now he's charged with his stepfather's murder.

image.altText: An unidentifiable woman holding a bag on heroin.

items.synopsis: Convincing recreational users to get their pills tested at Australia's first fixed drug-testing site is one thing – but cracking the community of Canberrans addicted to harder drugs, like heroin and ice, is another challenge entirely.

title.children: Worried by reports of fentanyl contamination in Australia's drug supply, Donna* got her heroin tested for the first time

image.altText: Alex de Minaur shouts and clutches his tennis racquet at the US Open.

items.synopsis: Australia's top-ranked player is into the US Open fourth round for just the third time in his career after rolling past 23rd seed Nicolas Jarry in straight sets.

title.children: Alex de Minaur puts on another dominant display in New York to reach US Open fourth round

image.altText: David Vandyke with horse

items.synopsis: Horse trainer David Vandyke prefers animals over people and in the early morning hours it's their company that keeps him grounded in the present.

title.children: Why horse trainer David Vandyke finds joy in early mornings and the company of animals

image.altText: A jar with Church written on it full of money.

items.synopsis: Major religions have a lot to say about wealth, but can you be truly religious at the same time? Christians, Muslims and Jews have differing views.

title.children: Racist stereotypes, mandated donations and the dangers of greed: Wealth and the three major religions

image.altText: An older man in a cap stands on his front door step holding a small blue-grey cat

items.synopsis: Rolf, 78, would rather die than leave his four cats, but there are no aged care homes that will allow them. Only one-in-five care homes in Australia are willing to consider pets.

title.children: Rolf says he'd 'rather die' than be forced by aged care to give up his cats

image.altText: Tottenham Hotspur manager Ange Postecoglou puts his arm around captain Son Heung-Min.

items.synopsis: Ange Postecoglou's Tottenham side beats Burnley 5-2 thanks to a Son Heung-min hat-trick, with Manchester City's Erling Haaland and Brighton teenager Evan Ferguson also tripling up on the same day of Premier League action.

title.children: Son Heung-min caps hat-trick with 16-pass 'Ange ball' special in Tottenham rout

image.altText: Two farmers look to camera in dry paddock in early 2000's

items.synopsis: From drought and bushfires to hail storms and flooding, El Niño's official declaration for the first time in eight years is likely to bring it all. Or maybe not. We look back at the impacts the major climate driver has brought to Australia in the past.

title.children: How might this year's potential El Niño compare to previous events?

image.altText: Five young adults wearing bright clothing and smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: The volunteers behind a community centre working to improve the wellbeing of adults who identify as LGBTQIA+, neurodivergent or disabled says they will fight to stay open despite rising costs.

title.children: Adelaide drop-in centre provides 'second home' to reduce isolation

image.altText: The frame of a house under construction.

items.synopsis: Experts say AI tools could help NSW to battle the mounting pressure on supplying housing, at a time when the state is forecast to be 134,000 dwellings short of the population-based target.

title.children: As NSW falls further behind in its housing targets, industry is urging the adoption of AI tech to meet demand

image.altText: Jen Matthews holding coral

items.synopsis: A team of scientists are getting creative about how to provide these underwater gardens with the best chance of survival against global warming, starting with coral found in Sydney Harbour.

title.children: How feeding 'little fat balls' to coral could combat damage from climate change

image.altText: A woman with brown high ponytail and fuchsia jumper holds a bouquet of flowers and poses in front of her landscape paintings

items.synopsis: Italian-born artist Eleonora Pulcini has exhibited her works all around the world, but at her Tasmanian gallery there's a catch. She doesn't let her customers buy a thing.

title.children: Tasmanian landscapes to hang in Italian Parliament, as expat artist shares love of adopted home

image.altText: Little boy is carried by mother in her arms. Both have cowboy hats on. Boy looks backwards at camera.

items.synopsis: Saleyards in rural Australia attract a unique kind of visitor, intrigued by the spectacle of livestock sales. And there is no better place to go behind the scenes than at Roma, in outback Queensland.

title.children: Cattle saleyards across the country becoming a hotspot for 'mesmerised' tourists

image.altText: Celia Pacquola, who has shoulder-length dark hair, smiles in a chit chat graphic, surrounded by visuals of what she divulged.

items.synopsis: Can Celia Pacquola pull off a cowboy hat? And other very important chats with the host of the Thank God You're Here reboot.

title.children: Celia Pacquola's fave biccie, revenge fantasy and what she wishes was behind her blue door

image.altText: Adam Liaw, smiling and holding a small child, stands with others adults around a table covered in bowls and food.

items.synopsis: From ways to protect kids in the lead-up to divorce, to keeping a calm heart and allowing tough questions, these four fathers have plenty of advice to offer dads.

title.children: 'I've always tried to acknowledge their mother': Four dads offer their fatherhood advice

image.altText: A woman wearing a sundress naps on the lap of a man wearing sunglasses as they sit on a park bench

items.synopsis: In the mornings, people rush to their work holding cups of coffee. Streets are filled with cars, and in the evenings restaurants are packed. But the details tell another story.

title.children: Life in Kyiv may seem normal on the surface. A closer look reveals the burdens of war

image.altText: 1980s TV with wattle bush on top sitting on a desk with globe

items.synopsis: John Farnham has fiercely protected his hit song You're The Voice from commercial use  until now.

title.children: John Farnham's You're The Voice is the soundtrack for the referendum Yes campaign

image.altText: Various history books are seen on a tabletop. One is about World War Two and another Indigenous Australians and Captain Cook.

items.synopsis: What we're taught about history in school helps shape our perception of the world and our place in it. But who decides what is taught, and what's being left out?

title.children: History might be written by the victors, but what happens when the victors change?

image.altText: Two women in a radio studio smiling to camera.

items.synopsis: Leigh Sales and Lisa Millar started their careers at a time when TV news looked a lot like the big-hair, big-shoulder pad, big-personality newsroom depicted in The Newsreader. They take us behind the scenes of their 30 years in journalism.

title.children: Leigh Sales and Lisa Millar on scoops, stuff-ups and 30 years of friendship

image.altText: A large black cockatoo sitting on a branch.

items.synopsis: For the first time in more than 20 years, glossy black cockatoo nests are discovered on the NSW Mid North Coast, in an area ravaged during the Black Summer bushfires.

title.children: 'A massive step forward': Rare glossy black cockatoo nests discovered in bushfire-damaged country

image.altText: a shadowy image taken looking towards the sunrise at a lookout looking over brisbane city

items.synopsis: Plans for a year-round light show at Mt Coot-Tha Botanic Gardens have been given the green light by Brisbane City Council, despite strong opposition from local residents and concern over the impact on local wildlife.

title.children: Lumina light show approved for Mount Coot-Tha despite community concerns
